Description: Digital photograph (colour); view of engraved rock art showing the pecked, infilled figure of an unidentified quadruped animal with four schematic legs, a long thick tail and either a bulbous head left without infill or a pair of horns connected in a loop above a narrow head. The animal is upright and facing right. There is a small disc of pecking in the centre of the circle made by the animal’s head/horns. To the upper left of the animal is another, smaller and unidentified, apparently with a pointed ear and upright tail (dog?). Below the central figure is the pecked outline of another, unidentified and cut off the edge of the image at the neck and trunk, with pecked schematic line pattern markings on the body. Random, interspersed pecking marks cover the entire tableau. A 5cm photo scale has been fitted at the base of the image. Wadi Hamra, Egypt. Scanned
Curator's comments: Wadi Hamra is a canyon-like valley with a relatively flat floor between one and 200m wide, curling more or less south into the Gilf Kebir plateau in Egypt’s Western Desert. There are three known rock art sites, all for engravings and first reported by Has Rhotert in 1952: The first is an old river terrace with numerous engravings of giraffe and a few of ostrich, cattle and abstract fan-shaped grooves, with stone circles and shallow depressions on the top. The second is several engravings further southwest. The third stands opposite the branch containing the first site: a rocky outcrop about 15 m high with a number of engravings along the base.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Trust for African Rock Art
